content.description: Sit start in the same obvious start as Flounder, but finish to the left.  Similarly awkward to Flounder, with a thrutchy little topout.  Good holds, good rock.
content.location: Left side of little overhanging boulder on the left side of the trail as you get into Mad Meadows.

content.description: A good problem with fun moves.  Work through the unusual rock, and top out straight up.  Along with Pocket Rocket, this is a great diversion before getting to the meat of Mad Meadows.
content.location: On the same boulder as Pocket Rocket, but on the more obvious arete with the large clearing underneath.

content.description: Sit start with your back on the slab, and climb the cool edges to the topout.  Good rock, good movement.
content.location: As you approach Mad Meadows, look down, and left to the very first boulder.  If you hit The Peephole boulder, you've gone too far.

content.description: Start on your choice of sidepull + gaston edges to go straight up and right to top out. Guidebook says to use this sloping edge above the start, but I skipped it with some stemming. Felt easier than the given V5 grade, but I might've started too high. It's harder to not dab on the tree than to top out.
content.location: The 1st boulder of Mad Meadows at the base of the main area Â It is behind the interesting table-top rock feature just next to the large tree

content.description: Flounder is a bit odd and awkward, but it's worth doing.  It's a short little thing, but the rock is as good as anywhere in Leavenworth.
content.location: The obvious overhang on the left as you come up the trail.  Pass the Pocket Rocket/Squarepusher boulder, and look for it on the left.  If you've gotten to the Peephole, you've gone too far.
